post_title: Snapchat turns off controversial 'Solar System' feature by default after bad press
post_content:
Snapchat, a popular multimedia messaging app, recently made an adjustment to its "solar system" feature based on feedback from users. The feature, which ranks paid subscribers by their position in their friends' solar system, has been met with mixed reactions, as it can lead to hurt feelings and anxiety when someone realizes they're not as close to a friend as they thought.

Snapchat+ subscribers can turn the feature on and off at their discretion, but by default, it is currently turned off. This change aims to balance the desire for the feature with the need to avoid upsetting those who do not want to use it.

The company has received criticism for the feature's potential negative impact on users' mental health, with some users experiencing anxiety and even breakups as a result of their position in their friends' solar system. However, Snapchat defends the feature by saying that people wanted to know more about their friendships and that features like solar system provide "additional awareness and context."

The solar system feature is just one of many friend ranking systems available on Snapchat. The app also offers a private feature called "Best Friends" that ranks the people with whom users communicate most, along with a heart or smiley emoji, and a much-debated feature called "Streaks" that encourages repeated use of the app by offering a visual representation of how many consecutive days users have stayed in touch with one another.

Despite criticism over the potential negative impact of these features, Snapchat has continued to build tools and features that have left it open to lawsuits and Congressional inquiry. However, the company promises to mitigate the potential downsides of online communication wherever possible.

In conclusion, while the solar system feature may provide some benefits to users, it is important for Snapchat to be mindful of the potential negative impact it may have on users' mental health and well-being. The company should continue to listen to feedback from users and make necessary adjustments to ensure that its features promote positive and healthy online interactions.
meta_desc:

post_title: Sundar Pichai on the challenge of innovating in a huge company and what he's excited about this year
title:
Title: Sundar Pichai on Nurturing Innovation, Risk-Taking at Alphabet & Google's Latest Advances

In a Stanford talk, Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai shares insights on fostering innovation in a giant company, focusing on risk-taking culture, incentives, and Google's latest tech advances, including LLM's multimodality.
post_content:
Title: Sundar Pichai's Insights on Leading Alphabet and Fostering Innovation

In a recent appearance at Stanford Graduate School of Business, Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai shared his thoughts on managing one of the world's most valuable technology companies and fostering innovation within a massive organization. The conversation offered valuable insights into Pichai's leadership style and priorities, as well as his concerns about the challenges that Alphabet faces in a rapidly evolving tech landscape.

Pichai acknowledged the difficulties of maintaining a culture of innovation in a company with over 200,000 employees, particularly when startups are constantly threatening to disrupt the business. He emphasized the importance of having a culture that encourages risk-taking, stating that larger organizations often become more risk-averse as they grow, despite the fact that smaller companies are more likely to make bold decisions that could potentially disrupt the market.

One of the critical challenges that Pichai highlighted is creating the right incentives to encourage innovation. According to Pichai, it's essential to reward effort and risk-taking, rather than just focusing on outcomes. This is because people may start taking conservative approaches if the focus is solely on outcomes, leading to a lack of innovation.

Pichai also discussed Google's efforts to recreate the culture of risk-taking that characterized its early years. He mentioned the revival of Google Labs, which aims to make it easier to prototype and test new ideas without worrying about the full brand or product development process. This approach allows for more experimentation and encourages employees to take risks.

When asked about the most exciting advances in technology this year, Pichai highlighted Google's latest LLM's multimodality. This feature enables the processing of different types of inputs, such as video and text, simultaneously. He also mentioned the potential of connecting discrete answers to provide smarter workflows, which could revolutionize various industries, such as healthcare.

In conclusion, Sundar Pichai's appearance at Stanford provided valuable insights into his approach to leading Alphabet and fostering innovation in a massive organization. By emphasizing the importance of risk-taking and experimentation, Pichai underscored the need for companies to remain agile and adaptable in a rapidly changing tech landscape. Encouraging a culture of innovation and creating the right incentives are crucial to staying ahead
meta_desc: "Discover Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai's insights on fostering innovation at Stanford. Learn about risk-taking, incentives, and multimodality. Act now!" {17 words}

post_title: IVP's Eric Liaw talks Klarna controversy, sticky successions, and why the great valuation reset doesn't really matter
title: IVP's Eric Liaw Discusses Fundraising, Klarna, and Global Growth
post_content:
Title: A Candid Conversation with Eric Liaw of IVP: Fundraising, Succession, and Portfolio Insights

Introduction

In the ever-evolving world of venture capital, Iron Venture Partners (IVP) has consistently made its mark by investing in growth-stage companies. With a diverse portfolio that includes Figma, Robinhood, and Klarna, IVP has maintained a strong presence in the industry. Recently, I had the opportunity to speak with General Partner Eric Liaw about the firm's recent fundraising, succession planning, and portfolio performance. This article presents the key takeaways from our conversation, edited for clarity and length.

Fundraising in a Choppy Market

When asked about the challenges of raising a new fund amidst the current market conditions, Liaw acknowledged the difficulties. "It's been a choppy period throughout," he admitted. Despite the challenges, IVP has maintained consistency in its fundraising strategy, ensuring it doesn't raise excessive capital and deploy it hastily. This approach has allowed the firm to remain resilient during market fluctuations.

IVP's LP Base and Global Presence
meta_desc:
Meta Description:

1. IVP raises funds consistently, ensuring it doesn't raise excessive capital and deploy it hastily.
2. Maintaining a close connection with existing LPs and developing new relationships is crucial for IVP's growth.
3. A gradual and well-planned transition between investment team members ensures continuity and sustainability.
4. The recent valuation reset in the venture capital space, including IVP's investment in Klarna, reflects changing market dynamics.

post_title: Canoo reveals it paid for CEO's jet, AT&T leaks records and X announces NSFW plans
title: Tech Roundup: YC Demo Days, Quantum Computing Breakthrough, Apple Home Robot
post_content:
Welcome to this week’s tech roundup, where we distill the most interesting developments in the world of technology into a concise and engaging format for our readers. Let’s dive in!

Y Combinator Demo Days:
Y Combinator, the renowned startup accelerator, held its Demo Days, and our venture desk team took a critical look at the presentations. Our coverage includes Day One, Day Two, as well as an AI roundup and insightful analysis from our dedicated editorial team.

Quantum Computing Breakthrough:
Microsoft and quantum computing startup Quantinuum announced a significant achievement in the field, claiming to have run thousands of experiments on a quantum computer without a single error. This milestone, long-sought in the industry, has the potential to revolutionize computing.

Apple’s Home Robot:
Following the cancellation of its autonomous EV project, Apple has reportedly shifted its focus to home robotics. While details are still sparse, it appears that Apple Home and AI executives are leading some form of household robotics project.

Noteworthy News:

 Canoo, the EV startup, paid $1.7 million in 2023 for its CEO’s private jet rental, which is double the revenue it generated that year.
 AT&T has reset millions of account passcodes after a massive data leak containing customer records was made public.
 OpenAI has made its flagship conversational AI, ChatGPT, accessible to everyone, regardless of account status.
 Microsoft has unbundled its Microsoft 365 and Office 365 subscription services, excluding Teams following pressure from EU regulators and complaints from rival Slack.

Ghost Autonomy Shutdown:
Ghost Autonomy, a startup developing autonomous driving software for automaker partners, has closed its doors after raising nearly $220 million.

Analysis:
Ron dives into the potential implications of a possible acquisition of HubSpot by Alphabet, Google’s parent company. While the deal could make sense financially, the two companies have distinct cultures and product offerings that could make for a challenging integration.

Podcasts:
Our podcasts this week feature an episode of Equity discussing BlaBlaCar’s new credit facility, as well as an episode of Found featuring

post_title: New U.S. ‘green bank’ aims to steer over $160B in capital into climate tech
title:
Title: "Green Bank's $20B Unlocks $160B for Climate Tech & Underserved"

The new U.S. Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund, or 'green bank,' will steer over $160B into climate tech, targeting smaller projects and underserved communities with $14B in loans. This fund is expected to spur $7-12 in private investment per dollar, playing a crucial role in achieving net-zero emissions by 2050. Equity investments and technological innovation are also encouraged.
post_content:
Title: The New U.S. Green Bank: A Game-Changer for Climate Tech

A long-awaited development in the clean energy sector has finally come to fruition. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) recently announced the allocation of $20 billion in grants from the Inflation Reduction Act to eight organizations, marking the creation of a 'green bank.' This new institution aims to steer over $160 billion in capital into climate technology projects, with a particular focus on smaller-scale initiatives that have been historically overlooked by traditional financial institutions.

Smaller projects, such as installing heat pumps in residential homes or retrofitting affordable housing, have often been deemed less lucrative and, therefore, less appealing to banks. However, the demand for such initiatives is undeniably present. This is where the green bank enters the scene, providing much-needed underwriting for these projects.

The green bank, officially known as the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund, will allocate over $14 billion to communities often underserved by financial institutions, including tribal, rural, low-income, and disadvantaged communities. The funds will be provided in the form of loans, which can then be recycled once repaid, creating a self-sustaining model.

The Connecticut Green Bank serves as a prime example of the potential success of such a model. With a delinquency rate that mirrors other commercial lenders across both residential and commercial portfolios, green bank loans have proven to be a viable and effective financing method.

But the impact of the green bank extends beyond its initial $20 billion budget. It is expected to attract $7 in private capital for every dollar dispersed, potentially even exceeding $12 of private investment per dollar, as suggested by a McKinsey study. This ability to spur private investment is crucial, as the U.S. is estimated to require $27 trillion by 2050 to achieve net-zero carbon emissions.

The green bank also presents opportunities for founders and investors. While the funding is primarily aimed at consumers and small businesses, equity investments are a possibility. Moreover, the increased demand for proven, commercially viable climate technologies should incentivize further innovation and development in this sector.

For those working on climate technologies not yet ready for commercial deployment, the green bank's loans can have a ri

post_title: Tesla will unveil a robotaxi on August 8, according to Musk
title: Tesla's Robotaxi Unveiled on August 8: Affordable EV Fate?
post_content:
Title: Tesla's Robotaxi Set to Launch Amidst Speculations of Affordable EV Cancellation

Introduction

In a recent announcement, Tesla's enigmatic CEO, Elon Musk, revealed that the electric vehicle (EV) manufacturer would unveil a robotaxi on August 8. This disclosure followed closely on the heels of a Reuters report asserting that Tesla had abandoned its plans to develop a low-cost EV. In response to the report, Musk took to Twitter, accusing Reuters of publishing falsehoods (again). This article delves into the implications of these recent developments and explores the future of robotaxis and affordable EVs in Tesla's product lineup.

The Robotaxi Reveal

Elon Musk's confirmation of the impending arrival of a Tesla robotaxi has generated considerable excitement in the industry. This announcement comes after Tesla decided to forgo radar and other sensors in its driver assistance technologies a few years back, relying solely on camera-based systems. The shift towards a camera-only system raises questions about how Tesla will ensure the safety and efficiency of its robotaxis, as competing companies like Waymo heavily rely on radar and lidar technologies in their autonomous vehicles.

Addressing the Affordable EV Elephant in the Room

Reuters reported that Tesla had scrapped its plans for an affordable EV, a claim Musk vehemently denied on Twitter. While it remains unclear which aspect of the report Musk was contesting, the fact that a robotaxi is indeed on the horizon suggests that the CEO may have been referring to the news organization's claim about the low-cost EV.

Tesla has long been promising a more budget-friendly model, with prices initially projected to start at $25,000. Musk himself expressed optimism in January this year that the vehicle would debut in the latter half of 2025. However, Tesla's most affordable vehicle currently is the Model 3, with a starting price of $39,000, leaving many potential buyers unable to afford the brand's eco-friendly offerings.

Maintaining Factual Accuracy and Core Message

According to Musk, Tesla is moving full speed ahead with its robotaxi plans,
